Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A soldier (passerby) in an inn pays with pieces of gold that turn out to be buttons (small bones). When the innkeeper takes the soldier to court, the soldier hypnotizes the judge so that he thinks a flood is occuring. He is forced to go through a series of adventures without leaving the room. Returning to his senses, the judge acquits the soldier. (2) A soldier tells tales & by his magic power makes an inn-keeper believe that he is a bear, that the soldier is a wolf, & that they are being chased by dogs, etc. The innkeeper falls out of his bed & comes to his senses.

Classifications: The Man Who Flew like a Bird & Swam Like a Fish
Variation Example: A man (youngest of three brothers, cheated heir) is given the power of transforming himself into animals of earth, air, & water by an old man in return for his hospitality (construction of a bridge) or by grateful animals whom he had helped. He goes into the service of a king who has departed for war & has forgotten an (two) important object (magic sword, magic ring, telescope, war documents, gloves). The king promises his daughter to whoever can deliver the forgotten object immediately. The soldier offers his help. He reaches the castle fast by swimming as a fish, flying as a bird, & running as a rabbit. He presents himself to the princess in his different transformations. She gives him the forgotten object & keeps a piece of his scale, pelt, a bit of fur, & a feather for herself. On his return the soldier is killed by an envious rival. The murderer takes the forgotten object & claims the reward. When the princess asks to see a second demonstration of the trans-formations, the cheater fails. She refuses to marry him & her father threatens to execute her. The soldier, resuscitated by his magic helpers, arrives at the last moment, proves his identity (identification by feather & marries the princess. The cheater is condemned to death.)

During the feast of Adonis in Sestos, Leander sees Hero, a priestess of Aphrodite, falls in love with her at first sight, & wins her love. Hero has been consigned to celibacy, so the lovers can only meet secretly. Leander swims every night through the Hellespont strait to see Hero who shines a light from the tower for him. One stormy night the light goes out & Leander is drowned. Hero sees his body & plunges into the sea to be united with him in death.

A boy, who had been promised by his father in a crisis to a wood spirit (demon, drakos), receives from the latter the power to transform himself into various animals. He frees a princess who had been kidnapped by the demon, & is thrown into the sea by a treacherous nobleman who claims to have rescued the princess. The cheater is exposed, & the boy marries the princess.

A grateful snake gives a man the power to understand animal languages, & tells him that if he reveals the secret, he must die. Once the man hears animals talking & laughs. His curious wife insists on knowing why he does so. Worn down by her nagging, he is about to give in & tell her. Then he hears a rooster say how easily he rules his many wives, while the man cannot rule even his one wife. The man keeps his secret & does not tell her anything.

A newly married woman who knows animal languages hears jackals (other animals) saying that a corpse floating in the river has a valuable ring on its finger. She pulls the corpse from the river & removes the ring. (In order to remove the ring she has to bite off the finger. Her husband sees her, believes her to be a cannibal ogress, & decides to return her to her family.) En route she overhears animals (birds) talking about where a treasure is hidden. Her husband learns the truth & they are reconciled. (The husband stays to guard the treasure & the wife goes to get her father-in-law. When he sees her returning alone, he concludes she has killed his son & is returning to kill him, & slays her before she has a chance to speak.)

A young man learns the languages of dogs, birds, & frogs. His father, angry at such useless knowledge, drives him out & orders him to be killed. A compassionate servant lets him escape & substitutes an animal’s heart as proof for the murder. By means of his knowledge of the dogs’ language the boy Discovers a treasure (he cures a sick princess & marries her later). Through his knowledge of the frogs’ language he learns that he will be elected pope. When he arrives in Rome, two doves come to sit on his shoulders & he is recognized as a man worthy of being pope (birds indicate his election as pope). The two doves tell him what to do so that he will be elected pope, & give him advice on how to act.

A farmer, overhearing the conversation of animals talking (during Christmas, New Year’s or Easter night), finds that he is to die (is warned of death) the next day (very soon). The prediction comes true.

A boy understands the language of birds & can in-terpret dreams. A merchant takes the boy in payment for goods & orders him to be slaughtered. He wants to eat the boy’s heart & liver in order to obtain his wisdom. The boy escapes. The merchant is called to the king to interpret a dream. He cannot do this. The boy arrives, interprets the dream, & exposes the merchant.

This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with a serpent’s crown. (1) A man steals a serpent’s crown. When the serpent pursues him he throws his garment behind him. A cook cooks the crown & learns the language of animals (and/or receives wealth). (2) A girl finds the crown (stone) of a serpent which it had laid down (lost). The serpent dies (kills itself from sorrow). (3) A good-natured maidservant shares milk with a (sick) serpent (wearing a crown) & is chased away by a farmer. When the maidservant marries a (rich) shepherd, the serpent, still grateful for the milk, appears at her wedding & lays down its crown of silver & gold. Or, the serpent gives her its crown in return for her sharing her milk. Later, the maidservant, at her wedding, thanks the snake for its help & returns the crown.

A sorcerer undertakes to expel snakes from a certain region. He succeeds in decoying the king of the snakes (white crowned snake), but dies from a snakebite (is carried off into the earth with the snakes).

A woman who owns (is friendly with) a magic serpent is raped by a prince. The woman asks the serpent, who witnessed the act of violence, to testify that the prince should marry no one else. (A prince calls a serpent to witness that he will marry a farmwife.) When the prince is about to marry a beautiful princess, the serpent twists itself about his neck. The first woman comes & frees him from the serpent on the condition that he marries her. (The serpent appears at the prince’s wedding, twists itself about his neck, & unwinds itself only when he will marry the farmwife.)

A farmer falls into a pit in which there are serpents (and a dragon). He sees a serpent licking a (white) stone, imitates it & stays alive without food or drink. Finally (in spring-time) he is rescued from the pit by a big serpent.

Contrary to a warning, a servant (cook) eats the flesh of a white serpent (from the king’s pot), whereupon he understands the speech of animals (birds). Or, a boy (driver) tastes the meat of a white snake that has been prepared by a healer (farmer), whereupon he understands the language of the grass & trees. When he is accused of stealing a ring this knowledge enables him to prove his innocence. By overhearing the conversation of ducks he learns that one of them has swallowed the queen’s ring that fell from the window. He orders the duck to be slaughtered, the ring is found, & he is saved. (He learns that the ring is in the stomach of a grateful fish, who brings it back.

A princess, abandoned by or separated from her husband, gives birth to a son. The son is taken from her by trickery & he grows up without knowing his true mother. When grown up, he sees his mother, falls in love with her, & goes to her at night to become her lover. On the way he overhears animals (calves) talking & learns the truth.

A lazy stupid boy releases a fish (frog, serpent, supernatural being), which gives him the power of making all his wishes come true. The lazy boy then makes an axe cut trees itself, water carry itself, a wagon move itself, an oven carry him, etc. When the princess laughs at him, he wishes her pregnant (from eating an apple, etc.). She does not know the father of her beautiful child. The king orders a test of paternity, & the child picks the lazy boy out as father (by handing him an apple, ball, golden ball). The king orders father & mother (and child) to be abandoned in a cask in the sea (in the mountains). By the power of wishing they reach land. The young man wishes to be beautified & makes a castle appear next to the king’s. When the king comes to visit, the young man wishes that an object (golden apple, golden cup) would appear in his pocket. The king is accused of stealing. Thus he is shown that the appearance of guilt & innocence (unwitting pregnancy, unwitting theft) is often deceptive.

Classifications: Iron is More Precious than Gold
Variation Example: An unlucky man asks his king for advice about what he should do. The princess advises him to marry because the luck of his wife (children) could counteract his own bad luck. The king allows him to marry the princess. When she sends him out to sell her needlework, he trades it for (threefold) pieces of good advice. He does not dare to return home without any money & finds work on a ship. When the ship is becalmed, he is sent down to the bottom of the sea to repair it, & there he settles a quarrel between two spirits: What is more precious (more useful, harder): gold (diamond, silver, copper) or iron (steel, copper)? He gives a (diplomatic) answer (following the first good advice). He receives a bag of (precious) stones as a reward & re-turns to the ship. Together with the merchants he reaches a strange country where the king favors him because of his jewels. The merchants are jealous & make a bet as to who is the richest of them. Following the second advice, he wins the wager & with it all the servants & the ship. He continues to travel & trades for 7–30 years. Finally he returns home & finds his wife sleeping between two strange men. When he is about to kill all three, he remembers the third piece of advice, to think before he acts. He finds that the men are his two grown-up sons.
A boy (man) who is skilled in playing an instrument finds himself in a submarine kingdom, entertains the king of the sea, chooses a bride for himself, & returns to earth.

Classifications: The King Transfers His Soul to a Parrot
Variation Example: A king learns how to transfer his soul into dead bodies & so does his servant (another person). The king transfers his soul into a parrot, & the servant transfers his soul into the king’s body. The queen discovers the truth. She tricks the servant into leaving the body of the king, & the king returns to his own body.

This misc. type comprises various tales mostly from China & other east Asian areas, dealing with a ruler who learns about the relativity of time. In Chinese variants he experiences a long space of time in a moment by having a dream (sometimes caused by drugs), in Indian variants by putting his head underwater, in other (often Asian) variants, the vision takes place by magic.

A man (philosopher, St. Augustine), meditating on the mystery of the Trinity, sees a child trying to empty the sea into a little hole at the shore. The child states that he could better bail out the sea with a thimble than the man would be able to understand the secret of the Trinity. The child disappears.

(Tom Thumb) A childless couple wish for a child, however small he may be. They have a boy (by supernatural birth) the size of a thumb. Thumbling takes food to his father on the farm & drives the wagon (plow) by sitting in the horse’s (ox’s) ear. He allows himself to be sold to strangers & then runs away from them. He lets himself be sold to thieves & accompanies them while they steal. Thumbling either helps them or he betrays them by his shouting; he then robs the thieves. He is swallowed by a cow, talks from the cow’s insides & reappears (in the sausage prepared from the intestines of the slaughtered cow). Someone takes the intestines (sausage) and, frightened by Thumbling’s voice inside, throws them away. Thumbling is swallowed by a wolf (fox) who eats the intestines. He talks from the wolf’s belly & the wolf becomes sick & frightens (warns) shepherds. The wolf dies (is killed) & Thumbling is rescued, or he persuades the wolf to take him to his father’s house.

The giant’s daughter takes a farmer with his plow & animals from a field, shows them to her father, & asks what sort of worms these are. The giant-father orders her to put the farmer back, because the farmer belongs to the race that will drive away the giants.

An aged, childless couple build (carve) them-selves a child from snow. When the child goes into the forest (jumps over a fire), it melts. Or a beautiful girl made from snow organizes a competition. She promises to marry any man who can overtake her on horseback, while she runs. By her magic actions (obstacles), she manages to leave all her suitors behind by magic actions (obstacles). The son of the emperor recognizes the magic, conjures the girl in the name of God to stop, & takes her up on his horseback. When they reach the top of a hill, the girl has disappearsed.In some variants the girl is made from gold & stays dumb until she is addressed by her name.

A prince wants to marry a true princess, but he cannot find one. One evening a young woman arrives at his palace pretending to be a true princess. The queen tests her by putting a pea under 20 (more or fewer) mattresses in her bed. The next morning the woman complains that she has slept badly because of something hard in her bed. Her sensitivity is proof that she is a real princess. The prince marries her at once.

A husband becomes pregnant by eating a magic fruit (fish) meant for his barren wife. He gives birth (from his knee) to a girl. The girl is abandoned & a bird rears her in a tree. A prince notices the reflected image of the (mute) girl in the water & falls in love with her. An old woman lures the girl down from the tree & she is captured & forced to marry the prince. The prince’s mother mutilates his wife during his absence & chases her away. The girl is given supernatural help. The prince’s mother disguises herself as his wife & they have sexual intercourse. The mother becomes pregnant & asks the servants to bring a special fruit. While looking for the fruit they hear a verse that reveals the truth, & they become mute. The prince himself looks for the fruit, learns the truth & is reunited with his wife. His mother is punished.

A prince grows tired of his wife because she cannot talk any more. He brings a new bride who insults the wife. The first wife starts to speak again. The prince rejects his new bride & lives with his first wife.

A man gives birth from his knee to several children. He puts them up in a tree & advises them not to lower the rope. A giant (wolf, other being) induces a child to lower the rope. The giant climbs up the tree & devours the children. When the father returns & realizes what has happened he fights with the giant & opens its belly (toe). All the children come out & become the ancestors of the various ethnic groups.

A girl has her hands cut off because she refuses to marry her father (because her father has sold her to the devil, forbids her to pray, her sister-in-law has slandered her to her brother). She is exposed in the forest & eats fruit from a garden. A king finds her in the forest (garden, stable, sea) & marries her in spite of her mutilation. She gives birth but is cast out along with her children, because her parents-in-law (father, mother, sister-in-law, devil) alter a letter from the king. During her second banishment her hands grow back again, usually restored by water (river, well, sea water), often with supernatural help (angel, saint, Virgin Mary, God). She is reunited with her husband.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A young woman of noble birth (nun) mutilates herself (by cutting off her eyes, hands, breasts, hair) to prevent the persecutions of a lover. She sends her eyes which he had admired, to her lecherous lover (brother, nobleman, bishop). (2) A man (priest) is tempted by the devil. He mutilates himself in order to keep his chastity (not to be tempted by the beauty of a [adopted] girl)

Classifications: The Father who Wanted to Marry his Daughter
Variation Example: (The Patient Helena, Helena of Constantinople, Mai & Beaflor.) Father (priest) wants to marry his daughter. She escapes, marries a prince, & gives birth to children. Her father kills the children (child) & puts a knife under her pillow as false evidence of murder. Her husband, believing that she has killed her children, condemns her. Her children are resuscitated by a miracle, & she is reconciled with her husband.

A pagan king promises his daughter (Wilgefortis, Liberta, Ontkommer, Kümmernis), who is a Christian, in marriage to another pagan king who has conquered his country. The daughter wants only to become a bride of the crucified Christ. In order to evade the forced marriage she prays to God to alter her appearance, & suddenly she grows a beard. Her angry father has her nailed to a cross, so that she will be like her beloved. As she dies, she prays for all who suffer pain or sorrow. Her father’s palace burns down.In some versions (The Shoe of St. Anthony) an old musician (fid-dler) plays for the crucified woman before she dies. She (her picture) thanks him by giving him her gold (silver) shoe (ring). The shoe is discovered in the possession of the musician, who is condemned as a thief. On his way to the gallows he asks to be allowed to play again in the collonade of the church. As soon as he begins to play, the holy picture of the crucified woman drops the other shoe for him, thus proving his innocence.

Three girls boast that if they marry the king they will have triplets with golden hair, a chain around the neck, & a star on the forehead. The king overhears the youngest & marries her. When she gives birth to three marvelous children the elder sis-ters substitute animals (dogs). She is imprisoned (banished), her children are exposed but are rescued by a miller (fisherman). When they have grown up, the eldest son sets out to find his father, to seek a speaking bird, a singing tree, or the water of life. He & his brother both fail & are transformed to marble columns. The sister, with the help of an old woman, succeeds in rescuing them & in bringing back the magic objects. The attention of the king is drawn to the children & the magic objects. The bird of truth reveals the whole story. The children & their mother are restored; the sisters are punished

Through the magic power of her evil stepmother, a princess gives birth to a monster (Wonder-Child) & is banished. The monster-child uses its magic powers to help its mother & forces a prince to marry her. The monster asks the prince to cut off its head whereupon it turns into a prince.

Snow White has a skin white as snow & lips red as blood. A magic mirror tells her stepmother that Snow White is more beautiful than she. The jealous stepmother orders a hunter to kill Snow White, but he substitutes an animal’s heart & saves her. Snow White goes to a house of dwarfs (robbers) who adopt Snow White as their sister. The stepmother now attempts to kill her by means of poisoned lace, a poisoned comb & a poisoned apple. The dwarfs succeed in reviving the maiden from the first two poisonings but fail with the third. They lay her in a glass coffin. A prince resuscitates her & marries her. The step-mother is made to dance herself to death in red hot shoes.

A girl goes into the forest to search for her nine brothers & stays with them (an abandoned child is reared in the forest by two storks). After they leave their sister in a tree, her fire goes out. Searching for fire, she is finally given some by an ogress. Later the ogress follows the ashes that the girl has dropped & tries to kill her. The girl steps on poisoned nails (tooth, bone) left by the ogress & dies. Her brothers (storks) put her in a glass case. When a prince removes the nails (tooth, bone), the girl is resuscitated & marries the prince.

A father (unwittingly) promises his daughter to a supernatural figure. The Virgin Mary (Christ, saint) or a black woman (wicked stepmother, witch, sorcerer) takes the child into heaven (church, castle) or away in a black coach. The girl looks into a forbidden room, where she sees God (Christ, Virgin Mary), & her hair & finger become golden. Or, she sees enchanted men (black virgins, skeletons). The girl obstin-ately denies what she has seen, is struck dumb & banished into the wilderness. She marries a king & gives birth to three children. The Virgin Mary (foster-mother, stepmother, mother-in-law) takes away her children & the queen is accused of infanticide. When she is to be burned to death on the stake, the queen finally acknowledges her guilt (by keeping silence she delivers the black woman). She is rescued from death & from her dumbness & her children are given back to her.

A childless queen is advised by a witch how to have a child, but she breaks a condition connected with the advice. She has two girls, a very beautiful one & a deformed one (with an animal’s head). The ugly sister always assists the handsome one & finally marries a prince. On the wedding day she is transformed & becomes as pretty as her sister.

When her husband the emperor is away, Crescentia is accused of adultery by her lecherous brother-in-law (she locks him in a tower to escape his advances). She is rescued from death (drowning) by a fisherman & nurses the child of a duke. When she rejects a seducer, her foster-child is killed in revenge. She is accused of murder & banished again. Once again she is rescued (by St. Peter) from drowning. Crescentia develops miraculous healing powers & reaches a high position. Her husband & the various men whose love she has rejected come to her for healing. She is recognized by her husband (the emperor), & they go to live in a monastery (convent)

Classifications: The Mother Who Did Not Bear Me but Nourished Me
Variation Example: A stepdaughter is falsely accused of bearing her sister’s illegitimate child & she & the child are expelled. Wherever they go, famine ceases & magic abundance comes. But famine comes to places they have left. Later the truth is revealed by the child’s behavior.
